occurrences.line_text: And to his brest it selfe intended right:
That made him reele, and to his brest his beuer bent.
Then on his brest his victour foote he thrust:
Gan sucke this vitall aire into his brest,
Against the Pagans brest, and therewith thought
Else mote it needes downe to his manly brest
An open passage through his riuen brest,
And crusht his carkasse so against his brest,
His stubborne brest gan secret pleasaunce to embrace.
Her snowy brest was bare to readie spoyle
Sith it is shrined in my Soueraines brest,
But fairest knight aliue, when armed was her brest.
And riue with thousand throbs thy thrilled brest;
My feeble brest of late, and launched this wound wyde.
Her alablaster brest she soft did kis,
But loue, that is in gentle brest begonne,
And housed is within her hollow brest,
Strooke her full on the brest, that made her downe
Of his hard hap did vexe his noble brest,
Euer to creepe into his noble brest,
Long while he stroue in his courageous brest,
In gentle Ladies brest, and bounteous race
She bath'd her brest, the boyling heat t'allay;
He knockt his brest with desperate intent,
And bowd his battred visour to his brest:
The hart out of his brest: for sith her ded
Dropped adowne vpon her yuorie brest:
So firmely she had sealed vp her brest.
Both by the burning hart, which on his brest
Whilest deadly torments do her chast brest rend,
Sith powre of hand, nor skill of learned brest,
Loue to conceiue in her disdainfull brest;
Dwels in thy bounteous brest? what couldst thou more,
Did beat and bounse his head and brest full sore;
And brushing his faire brest, did her inuade;
For priuy loue his brest empierced had,
Her brest all naked, as net iuory,
That little drops empurpled her faire brest.
Her bleeding brest, and riuen bowels gor'd,
It would haue cleft his braine downe to his brest.
Ne suffred sleepe to settle in his brest.
This feeble brest endured hath, but none
And all his hairy brest with gory bloud was fild.
At length did marke about her purple brest
Of his old loue, conceau'd in secret brest,
And inward grudge fild his heroicke brest:
Right in the midst, whereas they brest to brest
Right in the midst, whereas they brest to brest
Which long concealing in her couert brest,
Within the closet of her couert brest:
Her inward brest, and in her entrayles fryde,
Could sleepe all night, that in vnquiet brest
About her eares, does beat her brest, & forhead knockes.
That all her garments from her snowy brest,
And flame forth honour in thy noble brest:
And well disburdened her engrieued brest,
Her yuorie necke, her alablaster brest,
Readie to launce her brest, and let out loued life.
With that they hold: each hath his fortune in his brest.
Ne him could find to fancie in her brest:
Dinting his brest, had bred his restlesse paine,
That he no word could speake, but smit his brest,
That he his face, his head, his brest did beat,
Vpon the litle brest like christall bright,
Was dighting her, hauing her snowy brest
For on her brest I with these eyes did vew
Rent vp her brest, and bosome open layd,
Your yron brestes, or pittie could find place,
And beat their brests, and naked flesh to teare.
And suncke so deepe into their boyling brests,
In liuing brests, ykindled first aboue,
In their sterne brests, on him which late did driue
And her lancke loynes vngirt, and brests vnbraste,
Out of their brests, that streames of bloud did rayle
And Psamathe, for her brode snowy brests;
And rends her golden locks, and snowy brests embrew.
Sometimes she laught, that nigh her breth was gone,
The eldest of three brethren, all three bred
Then gin the blustring brethren boldly threat,
And Paynim brethren foyld.
And to those brethren said, Rise rise by liue,
Tho turning to those brethren, thus bespoke,
After the Paynim brethren conquer'd were,
Then gan the bloudie brethren both to raine:
Then all the sonnes of these fiue brethren raynd
Two brethren were their Capitains, which hight
Then Elfar, who two brethren gyants kild,
And those two brethren Giants did defend
And all sixe brethren, borne of one parent,
Strong warre vpon the Paynim brethren, hight
And warnd his other brethren ioyeous,
Tho to his brethren came: for they were three
Through which he follow should his brethren bad,
Whom with his brethren Timias slew, befell:
Some of borne brethren, prov'd vnnaturall;
Amongst those knights there were three brethren bold,
Three bolder brethren neuer were yborne,
The battell twixt three brethren, with
Soone after did the brethren three aduance,
Into his other brethren, that suruiued,
For lifes succession in those brethren three.
Yet were they brethren both of halfe the blood,
Neleus and Pelias louely brethren both;
Then came those sixe sad brethren, like forlorne,
And there the three renowmed brethren were,
two brethren that doe strive,
Both brethren, whom one wombe together bore,
Then weete ye Sir, that we two brethren be,
Those two false brethren, on that perillous Bridge,
And all his brethren borne in Britaine land;
Briana wexe more mylde.
This Castle, is by name Briana hight.
But when Briana saw that drery stound,
To take Briana for his louing fere,
The sad Briana, which all this beheld:
Sir Brianor, so sore, that none him life behote.
Or to his part allures, and bribeth vnder hand.
A stately Pallace built of squared bricke,
Not built of bricke, ne yet of stone and lime,
But being faire and brickle, likest glasse did seeme.
Amidst the bridale feast, whilest euery man
So both agreed, that this their bridale feast
And askt him where, and when her bridale cheare
That Theseus her vnto his bridale bore,
And deck with dainty flowres their bridall bed,
Faire ympe of Phoebus, and his aged bride,
Of niggard Nature, like a pompous bride
All bent to mirth before the bride was bedded,
Then came the Bride, the louely Medua came,
Where he her spous'd, and made his ioyous bride.
And Phoebus fresh, as bridegrome to his mate,
The bridegromes state, the brides most rich array,
Soone after whom the louely Bridegroome came,
The bridegromes state, the brides most rich array,
A bridge of bras, whose sound heaue[n]s thunder seem'd to bee.
It was a bridge ybuilt in goodly wize,
Ouer his Bridge, albee he rich or poore,
For on a Bridge he custometh to fight,
But by that Bridge, whereas he doth abide:
Where on the Bridge he ready armed saw
And wicked customes of that Bridge refourmed.
Those two false brethren, on that perillous Bridge,
Till to the perillous Bridge she came, and there
The other ouer side the Bridge she cast
And flancked both the bridges sides along,
Till to the Bridges vtter gate I came:
That keepes a Bridges passage by strong hond,
Till to the Bridges further end she past,
Whose bridle rung with golden bels and bosses braue.
That to affections does the bridle lend;
Giuing the bridle to her wanton will,
Into his mouth his maystring bridle threw,
Subdue desire, and bridle loose delight,
Then foming tarre, their bridles they would champe,
Bridling his will, and maistering his might:
Then heare the storie sad, which I shall tell you briefe.
By which to ease he him recured briefe,
Which spent in vaine, at last she told her briefe,
With briers and bushes all to rent and scratcht;
Who through thicke woods and brakes & briers him drew,
And called Brigadore (so was he hight)
As when two warlike Brigandines at sea,
A lawlesse people, Brigants hight of yore,
Now made the spoile of theeues and Brigants bad,
Hither those Brigants brought their present pray,
Such was the conflict of those cruell Brigants there.
Albe with all their might those Brigants her did keepe.
This wofull tale? or how those Brigants vyle,
And all the Brigants flocking in great store,
Faire Pastorella from those Brigants powre,
And with them eke, O Goddesse heauenly bright,
As the great eye of heauen shyned bright,
Of her, that was the Lady of that Pallace bright.
And a rich throne, as bright as sunny day,
Yet her bright blazing beautie did assay
And in her hand she held a mirrhour bright,
With which the armes, that earst so bright did show,
That all the aire it fils, and flyes to heauen bright.
Who when she saw Duessa sunny bright,
All stand astonied at her beautie bright,
From flaming mouth bright sparkles fierie red,
Of Gloriane great Queene of glory bright,
Out of the earth, with blade all burning bright
In that bright shield, and all their forces spend
With that fire-mouthed Dragon, horrible and bright?
To that most glorious house, that glistreth bright
And that bright towre all built of christall cleene,
And this bright Angels towre quite dims that towre of glas.
For as the clashing of an Armour bright,
His blazing eyes, like two bright shining shields,
High brandishing his bright deaw-burning blade,
And high her burning torch set vp in heauen bright.
Perforce rebutted backe. The weapon bright
As bright as doth the morning starre appeare
For feare of euill fates, but burnen euer bright.
Which else could not endure those beames bright,
And marre the blossome of your beautie bright:
Their beuers bright, each other for to greete;
But when as him all in bright armour clad
Had slaine Sir Mordant, and his Lady bright:
But heauenly pourtraict of bright Angels hew,
So passing persant, and so wondrous bright,
With golden aygulets, that glistred bright,
With that she swaruing backe, her Iauelin bright
Thus lowly to abase thy beautie bright,
One in bright armes embatteiled full strong,
Vpon the trembling waue, so shined bright,
With his bright blade did smite at him so fell,
Which she in Stygian lake, ay burning bright,
With wrathfull fire his courage kindled bright,
And his whot fire burnes in mine entrails bright,
Faire shields, gay steedes, bright armes be my delight:
And hundred fornaces all burning bright;
Their fruit were golden apples glistring bright,
And their bright Squadrons round about vs plant,
Two Paynim knights, all armd as bright as skie,
For why should a dead dog be deckt in armour bright?
Haue made thee souldier of that Princesse bright,
Alma she called was, a virgin bright;
Twise sixteen warders sat, all armed bright
Were made, and set in siluer sockets bright,
And to him gaue for wife his daughter bright,
There Alma like a virgin Queene most bright,
The windowes of bright heauen opened had,
Vprose Sir Guyon, in bright armour clad,
That euer brandished bright steele on hye:
And his bright shield, that nought him now auayld,
Tho when appeared the third Morrow bright,
Bright Scolopendraes, arm'd with siluer scales,
All pau'd beneath with Iaspar shining bright,
Which sparckling on the silent waues, does seeme more bright.
And with the wonder of her beames bright,
And snatching his bright sword began to close
That the bright glister of their beames cleare
From his Beauperes, and from bright heauens vew,
Breakes forth her siluer beames, and her bright hed
And her bright armes about her body dight:
Of lightning, through bright heauen fulmined;
Through whose bright ventayle lifted vp on hye
Sith a sore euill, which this virgin bright
Which shall breake forth into bright burning flame,
That now all Britanie doth burne in armes bright.
Where farre away one all in armour bright,
And griesly shadowes couered heauen bright,
Speed thee to spred abroad thy beames bright?
But Dwarfe aread, what is that Lady bright,
The goodly ornaments of beautie bright;
Or riue in twaine: which when that Lady bright
When the bright sunne his beams thereon doth beat;
Faire ympes of beautie, whose bright shining beames
That shall embellish more your beautie bright,
The sunne-beames bright vpon her body playd,
Her golden lockes, that late in tresses bright
The one of yron, the other of bright gold,
On the bright Sunne vnwares, doth soone withdraw
Then drew he his bright sword, & gan about him throw.
He did resemble to his Ladie bright;
Through the greene gras his long bright burnisht backe declares.
And thou, faire Phoebus, in thy colours bright
Also to win Deucalions daughter bright,
Beares in his boasted fan, or Iris bright,
And her bright browes were deckt with borrowed haire:
Without adorne of gold or siluer bright,
And streightly did embrace her body bright,
The snowy Florimell, whose beautie bright
Where is my part then of this Ladie bright,
And bright, that seemed borne of Angels brood,
One in bright armes, with ready speare in rest,
Another like, that were like faire and bright,
Hewing, and slashing shields, and helmets bright,
Whose beauties beame eftsoones did shine so bright,
The heauenly pourtraict of bright Angels hew.
For all afore that seemed fayre and bright,
Where hardly eye mote see bright heauens face,
The great Creatours owne resemblance bright,
Where when he saw the Prince in armour bright,
And were her vertue like her beautie bright,
Ne helmets bright, ne hawberks strong did spare,
And eke an hundred brasen caudrons bright,
With bright Chrysaor in his cruell hand,
Mounted in Phoebus charet fierie bright,
Him by the bright embrodered hedstall tooke:
Loue that same other Damzell, Lucy bright,
That flakes of fire, bright as the sunny ray,
Like coles, that through a siluer Censer sparkle bright.
Whereof there was great store, and armors bright,
That shone as bright, as doth the heauen sheene;
The Sunnes bright wayne to Phaetons decay,
And all their tops bright glistering with gold,
Whom seeing all in armour bright as day,
Vpon a throne of gold full bright and sheene,
Whose skirts were bordred with bright sunny beams,
Whose long rest rusted the bright steely brand;
As the bright sunne, what time his fierie teme
Begins to turne, and sunne to shine more bright,
So hideously vppon his armour bright,
Thereto addresse, and his bright shield display.
The armed Prince, with shield so blazing bright,
As prayse and honour? Or is ought so bright
And that bright sword, the sword of Iustice lent,
Of the bright mettall, shyning like Sunne rayes;
For beautie is more glorious bright and clere,
Like two great Beacons, glared bright and wyde,
And with his club bet backe his brondyron bright
Then he was tride vnto his Lady bright:
And doffing his bright armes, himselfe addrest
Through the bright heauen doth her beams display,
With starrie beames about her shining bright,
And twixt the twinckling of her eye-lids bright,
Vpon the litle brest like christall bright,
But soone the knights with their bright-burning blades
Her coleblacke curtein ouer brightest skye,
That dreaded Night in brightest day hath place,
Then gan her beautie shine, as brightest skye,
Like glauncing light of Phoebus brightest ray;
Panthea, seemd the brightest thing, that was:
That her broad beauties beam great brightnes threw
The whiles the passing brightnes her fraile sences dazed.
I, whether lately through her brightnesse blind,
That purest skye with brightnesse they dismaid:
To dim the brightnesse of her glorious throne,
So forth she comes: her brightnesse brode doth blaze;
For neuer did such brightnesse there appeare,
Both glorious brightnesse, and great terrour bred;
Such blazing brightnesse through the aier threw,
Through passing brightnesse, which did quite co[n]found
The blazing brightnesse of her beauties beame,
That with their brightnesse made that darknesse light,
His feeble eyne, with too much brightnesse dazed,
Did dim the brightnesse of the welkin round,
And with their brightnesse daz'd the straunge beholders eye.
Gins to abate the brightnesse of his beme,
It showes, and with her brightnesse doth inflame
The heauens bright-shining baudricke to enchace;
Came to a riuer, by whose vtmost brim
And to the brim with Colt wood did it fill,
Soone as they bene arriu'd vpon the brim
Vpon the brim of his brode plated shield,
The which was with Nepenthe to the brim vpfild.
Towards the westerne brim begins to draw,
But when as Calepine came to the brim,
Till to the brim I haue it full defrayd:
A full good pecke within the vtmost brim,
And in their entrails, full of quicke Brimston,
With fire and brimstone, which for euer shall remaine.
Enrold in duskish smoke and brimstone blew;
To reach the fruit, which grew vpon the brincke:
Aboue the brincke, to tread vpon the land,
Whiles the salt brine out of the billowes sprong.
His dewy lockes did drop with brine apace,
Come both, and with you bring triumphant Mart,
Faire Venus seemde vnto his bed to bring
Bidding the Dwarfe with him to bring away
To bring forth fruit, and make eternall derth,
They bring them wines of Greece and Araby,
So towards old Syluanus they her bring;
In hope to bring her to her last decay.
O welcome thou, that doest of death bring tydings trew.
As time in her iust terme the truth to light should bring.
Ne bring him forth in face of dreadfull fight,
She cast to bring him, where he chearen might,
That was fore by the way, she did him bring,
Vnto you bring, to ease you of your misery.
And to the world does bring long wished light;
And to the wished hauen bring thy weary barke.
He promised to bring me at that howre,
As griefe and furie vnto me did bring;
And planted there, did bring forth fruit of gold:
Bring the soule into captiuitie:
And witchcraft, she from farre did thither bring:
For loue does alwayes bring forth bounteous deeds,
Vnto these Sprights, to bring to perfect end.
Guided thy glaunce, to bring his will to pas:
To this his natiue soyle thou backe shalt bring,
He shall his dayes with peace bring to his earthly In.
Will bring, and shortly make you a mayd Martiall.
The which may bring my ship, ere it be rent,
To bring her sonne vnto his last decay.
To bring to passe his mischieuous intent,
And bring with him his long expected light?
Oft from the forrest wildings he did bring,
To bring her backe againe, or worke her finall bale.
And at the twelue monethes end should bring their names
And eke their lately bruzed parts to bring in plight.
One may his iourney bring too soone to euill end.
Bring foorth an infinite increase, that breedes
And sought to bring all things vnto decay;
She in short space did often bring to nought
Vnto his last confusion to bring,
To which all knights with them their Ladies are to bring.
These three so noble babes to bring forth at one clap.
And forth to bring those thrals, which there he held.
To bring forth stormes, or fast them to vpbinde,
To bring it to her husband new ordained,
Which that thou mayst the better bring to pas,
When thou hast all this doen, then bring me newes
And forth did bring a Lion of great might;
And bring in bondage of their brutishnesse:
That from your selfe I doe this vertue bring,
And bring vs bale and bitter sorrowings,
To bring him to the place, where he would faine,
But being growen strong, it forth doth bring
On which the first, whose force her first doth bring,
Vnlesse to me thou hether bring with speed
For being gone, none can them bring in place,
Yet none of them could euer bring him into band.
And bring into a mighty Peres displeasure,
And bringeth backe againe.
Who bringing them to their appointed place,
And bringing light into the heauens fayre,
Till that the morning, bringing earely light
And forth her bringing to the ioyous light,
brings Arthur to the fight,
O who is that, which brings me happy choyce
Is not short paine well borne, that brings long ease,
Her faithfull knight faire Vna brings
Brings them to ioyous rest and endlesse blis.
And after to his Pallace he them brings,
The sea vnto him voluntary brings,
Vnto the man, that of him tydings to her brings.
She with her brings into a secret Ile,
The roote, and brings forth glorious flowres of fame,
For passing ioy, which so great maruaile brings,
And to his daughter brings, that dwels thereby:
Talus brings newes to Britomart
Calidore brings Priscilla home,
Thou brings? aie me, is this the timely ioy,
From th'vtmost brinke of the Armericke shore,
At them he gan to reare his bristles strong,
As chauffed Bore his bristles doth vpreare,
And Bristow faire, which on his waues he builded hath.
Whom straunge aduenture did from Britaine fet,
The greater Britaine, here to seeke for prayse and fame.
Sith him whilome in Britaine she did vew,
And warlike people, which the Britaine Islands hold.
And all his brethren borne in Britaine land;
In auncient times vnto great Britainee,
High reard their royall throne in Britane land,
The gracious Numa of great Britanie:
That now all Britanie doth burne in armes bright.
And Locrine left chiefe Lord of Britany.
Of Brennus and Bellinus, kings of Britany.
And with their braunches spred all Britany,
Which they should hold of him, as subiect to Britayne.
And noblest borne of all in Britayne land;
Of British bloud, all sitting at his bord;
Of British armes doest maske thy royall blood,
Guyon encountreth Britomart,
Euen the famous Britomart it was,
The whiles faire Britomart, whose constant mind,
When Britomart him saw, she ran a pace
Perdie (said Britomart) the choise is hard:
With which faire Britomart gaue light vnto the day.
But to faire Britomart they all but shadowes beene.
But Britomart dissembled it with ignoraunce.
But Britomart would not such guilfull message know.
The Lady did faire Britomart entreat,
The Redcrosse knight to Britomart
Be thou faire Britomart, whose prayse I write,
Such secret ease felt gentle Britomart,
One day it fortuned, faire Britomart
Merlin bewrayes to Britomart,
It was not, Britomart, thy wandring eye,
The spouse of Britomart, is Arthegall:
Behold the man, and tell me Britomart,
Ah read, (quoth Britomart) how is she hight?
Faire Britomart, and that same Armory
The Redcrosse knight diuerst, but forth rode Britomart.
Bold Marinell of Britomart,
Cannot with noble Britomart compare,
But Britomart kept on her former course,
So the faire Britomart hauing disclo'st
Paridell giusts with Britomart:
Gainst Britomart, and euer closely eyde
Whenas the noble Britomart heard tell
There there (said Britomart) a fresh appeard
Faire Britomart and that same Faerie knight
With Britomart, so sore did him offend,
Britomart chaceth Ollyphant,
And of faire Britomart ensample take,
Whom when as Britomart beheld behind
But Britomart the flowre of chastity;
Faire Britomart so long him followed,
Greatly thereat was Britomart dismayd,
That wondrous sight faire Britomart amazed,
Whence Britomart redeemes faire
Bold Britomart, as she had late forecast,
Before faire Britomart, she fell prostrate,
But Britomart vprearing her from ground,
That Britomart halfe enuying their b[l]esse,
Fayre Britomart saues Amoret,
Vntill such time as noble Britomart
Yet Britomart attended duly on her,
From farre espide the famous Britomart,
Discourteous, disloyall Britomart,
And euermore sought Britomart to cleare.
Britomart winnes the prize from all,
The which this famous Britomart did beare;
So did the warlike Britomart restore
To Britomart was giuen by good right;
